item.title: Self-compressed waveform-stable light transients enabling water-window attosecond spectroscopy
item.author: Valentina Utrio LanfaloniFederico VismarraHans Jakob Wörner
item.content:encoded:
Researchers demonstrate phase-stable sub-cycle self-compressed light transients, as well as their sampling down to half of an optical cycle, and determine their waveform phase offset. They apply the transients to soft X-ray high-harmonic generation and attosecond X-ray absorption spectroscopy.

Valentina Utrio LanfaloniFederico VismarraHans Jakob Wörner

Nature Photonics

item.title: Material system enhances superconducting qubits
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
In the development of large-scale quantum processors, material improvements yield rapid progress because they can be readily translated to many devices and platforms. This work shows that, if they are built from tantalum and silicon, superconducting qubits can have millisecond-scale lifetimes and coherence times and reduced fabrication-related contamination.

Nature

item.title: Attosecond physics in optical near fields
item.author: Jonas HeimerlStefan MeierPeter Hommelhoff
item.content:encoded:
Attosecond control of electrons in nanostructures requires resolving dynamics in the optical near field. Now, an experiment finds low-energy spectral stripes that track subcycle electron emission and allow the isolation of attosecond electron bursts.

Jonas HeimerlStefan MeierPeter Hommelhoff

Nature Physics

item.title: iPEX enables micrometre-resolution deep spatial proteomics via tissue expansion
item.author: Fengxiang WangCuiji SunYilong Zou
item.content:encoded:
Isotropic tissue magnification is integrated with matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry imaging to enable untargeted spatial proteomics at micrometre resolution and with high protein identification rates in multiple tissue types.

Fengxiang WangCuiji SunYilong Zou

Nature

item.title: Photoinduced twist and untwist of moiré superlattices
item.author: Cameron J. R. DuncanAmalya C. JohnsonFang Liu
item.content:encoded:
Femtosecond photoexcitation drives a coherent twist–untwist motion of the moiré superlattice in 2° and 57° twisted WSe2/MoSe2 heterobilayers.

Cameron J. R. DuncanAmalya C. JohnsonFang Liu

Nature

item.title: Completely characterizing multimode second-order nonlinear optical quantum processes
item.author: Geunhee GwakChan RohYoung-Sik Ra
item.content:encoded:
A resource-efficient characterization method to completely characterize multimode second-order nonlinear optical quantum processes is demonstrated, satisfying the required physical condition. Scaling quadratically with the mode number, it enables complete 16-mode analysis.

Geunhee GwakChan RohYoung-Sik Ra

Nature Photonics

item.title: A fault-tolerant neutral-atom architecture for universal quantum computation
item.author: Dolev BluvsteinAlexandra A. GeimMikhail D. Lukin
item.content:encoded:
Dolev BluvsteinAlexandra A. GeimMikhail D. Lukin

Nature

item.title: Fractional quantization in insulators from Hall to Chern
item.author: B. A. BernevigL. FuJ. Shan
item.content:encoded:
This Review describes the concepts behind generalized quantum Hall effects that can take place without a magnetic field, and summarizes recent experimental manifestations of these phenomena in twisted two-dimensional materials and few-layer graphene.

B. A. BernevigL. FuJ. Shan

Nature Physics

item.title: Quantum light drives electrons strongly at metal needle tips
item.author: Jonas HeimerlAndrei RasputnyiPeter Hommelhoff
item.content:encoded:
The common description of strong-field light–matter interaction neglects the quantum-optical nature of the driving field. Now signatures of strong-field photoemission appear in electron energy spectra when driving with non-classical light.

Jonas HeimerlAndrei RasputnyiPeter Hommelhoff

Nature Physics

item.title: Quantum light steers photoelectrons
item.author: Marcelo Ciappina
item.content:encoded:
When driven by nonclassical light, photoemission from a needle tip reveals signatures of strong-field physics, opening up opportunities to control matter and to engineer the building blocks of quantum technologies.

Marcelo Ciappina

Nature Physics

item.title: Room-temperature spin-layer locking of exciton–polariton nonlinearities in a WS2 microcavity
item.author: Jiaxin ZhaoAntonio FieramoscaTimothy C. H. Liew
item.content:encoded:
A room-temperature double-layer WS2 microcavity is used to explore spin anisotropy and tune it with interlayer spacing.

Jiaxin ZhaoAntonio FieramoscaTimothy C. H. Liew

Nature Photonics

item.title: Millisecond lifetimes and coherence times in 2D transmon qubits
item.author: Matthew P. BlandFaranak BahramiAndrew A. Houck
item.content:encoded:
A materials platform using tantalum as a base layer and silicon as the substrate to construct superconducting qubits enables device performance improvements such as millisecond lifetimes and coherence times, as well as high time-averaged quality factors.

Matthew P. BlandFaranak BahramiAndrew A. Houck

Nature

item.title: Chinese scientists increasingly lead joint projects with the UK, US and Europe
item.author: Mohana Basu
item.content:encoded:
Although China needs to strengthen its leadership in artificial intelligence, semiconductors and energy, say researchers.

Mohana Basu

Nature

item.title: Quantum fusion of independent networks based on multi-user entanglement swapping
item.author: Yiwen HuangYilin YangXianfeng Chen
item.content:encoded:
The quantum fusion of two independent 10-user networks is demonstrated based on multi-user entanglement swapping. Active temporal and wavelength multiplexing schemes are developed to merge the two networks into a larger network with 18 users in the quantum correlation layer.

Yiwen HuangYilin YangXianfeng Chen

Nature Photonics

item.title: Free electrons as a source of nonclassical light
item.author: Sophie MeuretHugo Lourenço-Martins
item.content:encoded:
Photon sources used in quantum optics are limited in ways that free electron sources may not be. Now, accelerated electrons have been shown to generate non-classical light — this opens up possibilities for quantum experiments at the nanoscale.

Sophie MeuretHugo Lourenço-Martins

Nature Physics

item.title: Quadrature-dependent lattice dynamics of dissipative microcombs
item.author: Eran LustigMelissa A. GuidryJelena Vučković
item.content:encoded:
The quantum noise of Kerr combs is found to exhibit oscillatory lattice dynamics through state transitions, with implications for squeezing and comb formation.

Eran LustigMelissa A. GuidryJelena Vučković

Nature Photonics

item.title: Frequency-stable nanophotonic microcavities via integrated thermometry
item.author: Sai Kanth DachaYun ZhaoAlexander L. Gaeta
item.content:encoded:
Integrating a thin-film resistance thermometer above a high-Q SiN microresonator enables local temperature monitoring and active stabilization of its resonance wavelength. The emission wavelength of a distributed feedback laser locked to the microresonator fluctuates within 0.5 pm over a period of 50 h.

Sai Kanth DachaYun ZhaoAlexander L. Gaeta

Nature Photonics

item.title: Electrically tuning photonic topological quasiparticles in synthetic two-level system
item.author: Junhui JiaJianbin RenShenhe Fu
item.content:encoded:
Photonic quasiparticles are neutral, so controlling them by coupling with external fields is generally impossible. Now, by synthesizing a two-level photonic system, coupling with an electric field becomes possible and enables electrical control.

Junhui JiaJianbin RenShenhe Fu

Nature Physics

item.title: Observation of the nonlinear chiral thermoelectric Hall effect in tellurium
item.author: Tetsuya NomotoAkiko KikkawaFumitaka Kagawa
item.content:encoded:
Nonlinear thermoelectric transport arising from inversion-symmetry breaking has been predicted theoretically. Now, the nonlinear chiral thermoelectric Hall effect has been experimentally demonstrated for tellurium at room temperature.

Tetsuya NomotoAkiko KikkawaFumitaka Kagawa

Nature Physics

item.title: Identifying universal spin excitations in candidate spin-1/2 kagome quantum spin liquid materials
item.author: Aaron T. BreidenbachArthur C. CampelloYoung S. Lee
item.content:encoded:
The hunt for a quantum spin liquid has involved many different material families and models. Now, Zn-barlowite has been found to have similar behaviour to another candidate material, herbertsmithite, hinting there may be universal physical behaviour.

Aaron T. BreidenbachArthur C. CampelloYoung S. Lee

Nature Physics

item.title: A magnetic knob for strangeness
item.author: Edwin W. Huang
item.content:encoded:
High-field transport and ultrasound experiments in cuprates tie strange metallic T-linear resistivity to spin dynamics.

Edwin W. Huang

Nature Physics

item.title: The generalized quantum Stein’s lemma and the second law of quantum resource theories
item.author: Masahito HayashiHayata Yamasaki
item.content:encoded:
Earlier work establishing an analogue of the second law of thermodynamics for quantum resources relied on a flawed proof of the generalized quantum Stein’s lemma. Now the lemma has been re-proven, restoring the analogy.

Masahito HayashiHayata Yamasaki

Nature Physics

item.title: Many-body interference in kagome crystals
item.author: Chunyu GuoKaize WangPhilip J. W. Moll
item.content:encoded:
Experimental evidence of coherent charge transport in the normal state of the kagome metal CsV3Sb5 is presented, revealing the nature of correlated order in kagome metals and new directions for exploring quantum coherence in correlated electron systems.

Chunyu GuoKaize WangPhilip J. W. Moll

Nature

item.title: 3R-stacked transition metal dichalcogenide non-local metasurface for efficient second-harmonic generation
item.author: Zhi Hao PengMichele CotrufoChiara Trovatello
item.content:encoded:
Exploiting non-local optical resonances on 3R-MoS2 flakes, researchers demonstrate single-pass second-harmonic conversion efficiencies of ~10−4 over only 160-nm-thick van der Waals nonlinear metastructures at telecom wavelengths.

Zhi Hao PengMichele CotrufoChiara Trovatello

Nature Photonics

item.title: Does gravity produce quantum weirdness? Proposal divides physicists
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
A theoretical study suggests that gravity could have quantum effects without itself being a quantum theory. Other researchers aren’t so sure.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature

item.title: Daily briefing: People with cancer lived longer if they’d had a COVID-19 vaccine
item.author: Jacob Smith
item.content:encoded:
mRNA vaccines seem to ‘rev up’ the immune system to boost immunotherapy. Plus, a rare meteorite has been recovered from the Moon and the mysterious transition between wakefulness and sleep.

Jacob Smith

Nature

item.title: Entanglement theory with limited computational resources
item.author: Lorenzo LeoneJacopo RizzoSofiene Jerbi
item.content:encoded:
Previous work on the limits of quantum information processing has often assumed access to unlimited computational resources. Imposing a requirement for computational efficiency on entanglement theory substantially changes what is possible.

Lorenzo LeoneJacopo RizzoSofiene Jerbi

Nature Physics

item.title: Google claims ‘quantum advantage’ again — but researchers are sceptical
item.author: Elizabeth Gibney
item.content:encoded:
The firm says it has solved a problem on a quantum processor faster than a classical computer, and is optimistic about future scientific applications.

Elizabeth Gibney

Nature

item.title: Observation of constructive interference at the edge of quantum ergodicity
item.author: Dmitry A. AbaninRajeev AcharyaNicholas Zobrist
item.content:encoded:
Experimental measurements of high-order out-of-time-order correlators on a superconducting quantum processor show that these correlators remain highly sensitive to the quantum many-body dynamics in quantum computers at long timescales.

Dmitry A. AbaninRajeev AcharyaNicholas Zobrist

Nature

item.title: Classical theories of gravity produce entanglement
item.author: Joseph AzizRichard Howl
item.content:encoded:
By applying the full framework of quantum field theory, it is shown that local classical theories of gravity can transmit quantum information and, thus, generate entanglement through physical, local processes.

Joseph AzizRichard Howl

Nature

item.title: Individual solid-state nuclear spin qubits with coherence exceeding seconds
item.author: James O’SullivanJaime TravesedoEmmanuel Flurin
item.content:encoded:
Nuclear spins in solid-state systems can have very long coherence times, which makes them attractive for use as qubits. Now a nuclear spin qubit device has been developed with all-microwave two-qubit control that has important performance benefits.

James O’SullivanJaime TravesedoEmmanuel Flurin

Nature Physics

item.title: Practical limits on entanglement manipulation
item.author: Kun Fang
item.content:encoded:
Entanglement is a powerful resource for quantum technologies but real-world computation limits can drastically change what is achievable. Now research reveals that computational constraints reshape our understanding of entanglement manipulation.

Kun Fang

Nature Physics

item.title: Optimization by decoded quantum interferometry
item.author: Stephen P. JordanNoah ShuttyRyan Babbush
item.content:encoded:
Decoded quantum interferometry is a quantum algorithm that uses the quantum Fourier transform to reduce optimization problems to decoding problems.

Stephen P. JordanNoah ShuttyRyan Babbush

Nature

item.title: Is there a ‘smoking gun’ test for quantum gravity?
item.author: Zachary Weller-Davies
item.content:encoded:
Quantum-entanglement experiments have been proposed as a way to test whether gravity is quantum, but getting definitive proof might be harder than previously thought.

Zachary Weller-Davies

Nature

item.title: Cavity electrodynamics of van der Waals heterostructures
item.author: Gunda KippHope M. BretscherJames W. McIver
item.content:encoded:
Integrating an electronic device with a cavity can cause the electrons to couple to photons strongly enough to form hybrid modes. Now, the cavity effects induced by intrinsic graphite gates are shown to modify the low-energy properties of graphene.

Gunda KippHope M. BretscherJames W. McIver

Nature Physics

item.title: Demonstration of dynamic surface codes
item.author: Alec EickbuschMatt McEwenAlexis Morvan
item.content:encoded:
Typical quantum error correcting codes assign fixed roles to the underlying physical qubits. Now the performance benefits of alternative, dynamic error correction schemes have been demonstrated on a superconducting quantum processor.

Alec EickbuschMatt McEwenAlexis Morvan

Nature Physics

item.title: Electrons herald non-classical light
item.author: Germaine ArendGuanhao HuangClaus Ropers
item.content:encoded:
When free electrons emit light, an entangled electron–photon state is created. Here measurements of the correlated multiparticle system have been used to produce non-classical photonic states.

Germaine ArendGuanhao HuangClaus Ropers

Nature Physics

item.title: Efficient quantum thermal simulation
item.author: Chi-Fang ChenMichael KastoryanoAndrás Gilyén
item.content:encoded:
An efficient quantum thermal simulation algorithm that exhibits detailed balance, respects locality, and serves as a self-contained model for thermalization in open quantum systems.

Chi-Fang ChenMichael KastoryanoAndrás Gilyén

Nature

item.title: Spatial metabolic gradients in the liver and small intestine
item.author: Laith Z. SamarahClover ZhengJoshua D. Rabinowitz
item.content:encoded:
Mapping of spatial metabolic gradients in the mouse liver and intestine identifies fructose-induced focal derangements in liver metabolism.

Laith Z. SamarahClover ZhengJoshua D. Rabinowitz

Nature

item.title: Patchy nanoparticles by atomic stencilling
item.author: Ahyoung KimChansong KimQian Chen
item.content:encoded:
An atomic stencilling method based on the co-adsorption of iodide and 2-naphthalenethiol on gold is described, yielding more than 20 different types of nanoparticle with masked and painted regions and patchy particle morphologies not reported previously.

Ahyoung KimChansong KimQian Chen

Nature

item.title: Experimental observation of a time rondeau crystal
item.author: Leo Joon Il MoonPaul M. SchindlerAshok Ajoy
item.content:encoded:
Previous work on periodically driven many-body systems has demonstrated the formation of time crystals that break time-translation symmetry. Now, more general phases with partial temporal ordering have been realized.

Leo Joon Il MoonPaul M. SchindlerAshok Ajoy

Nature Physics

item.title: Ultrafast topological control
item.author: Hyun Gyu SongSu-Hyun Gong
item.content:encoded:
Exciton–polariton superlattices allow sub-picosecond switching of topological phases, paving the way for ultrafast and reconfigurable topological photonic devices.

Hyun Gyu SongSu-Hyun Gong

Nature Physics

Two decades ago this month, Nature Physics published its first issue. We reflect on the past and look into the future.

item.content:encoded:
Mark Buchanan

item.title: The first eight
item.author: Bart VerberckElizaveta DubrovinaSonal Mistry
item.content:encoded:
In our very first issue we published eight research papers, on topics ranging from condensed matter physics to atom interferometry. Two decades on, we look back at those works and hear from their authors.

Bart VerberckElizaveta DubrovinaSonal Mistry

Nature Physics

item.title: A quantum boost for ultra-precise clocks
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
The light frequency associated with changes in the energy state of atoms can be used to define the ticking of high-precision optical clocks. Experiments with ytterbium atoms have further enhanced the clocks’ precision by using a quantum amplification technique.

Nature

item.title: Quantum-amplified global-phase spectroscopy on an optical clock transition
item.author: Leon ZaporskiQi LiuVladan Vuletić
item.content:encoded:
The precision of determining the phase of an optical atomic clock is increased above the standard quantum limit in a new spectroscopic method.

Leon ZaporskiQi LiuVladan Vuletić

Nature

item.title: Groundbreaking quantum-tunnelling experiments win physics Nobel
item.author: Elizabeth GibneyDavide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
John Clarke, Michel Devoret and John Martinis discovered quantum physics on a macroscopic scale, paving the way for quantum computing.

Elizabeth GibneyDavide Castelvecchi

Nature

item.title: How to build a long-lived qubit
item.author: Nathalie de Leon
item.content:encoded:
Improvements in qubit performance are essential for the development of large-scale quantum computing devices. Sustained progress requires a broad approach combining physics, materials science, and engineering mindsets.

Nathalie de Leon

Nature Physics

item.title: Mathematical discovery in the age of artificial intelligence
item.author: Bartosz NaskręckiKen Ono
item.content:encoded:
In this comment, we consider how artificial intelligence tools are reshaping the way mathematical research is conducted and discuss how future developments of this technology will transform mathematical practice.

Bartosz NaskręckiKen Ono

Nature Physics
